column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: belivin4today, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been receiving the monthly naltrexone injections for about 9 months.  Other than injection site bruising and temporary swelling, I have had no other side effects.   In conjunction with other recovery regimes (AA, CBT)it has been very effective.  I am an alcoholic who would relapse, detox, maintain a few months sober and relapse again.  This medication, in conjunction with a solid recovery program, has removed all my cravings, obsessions and compulsions to drink despite the fact that  I have plenty of wreckage from my last drinking episode to make me want to crawl back into the bottle. My only question is how long does someone take this?  Is this something that people like me take for the rest of my life?

It has been prescribed in pill form in combination with morphine and two other C2 pain medications. I've not had a good exiperience with this drug.

column1: Prevention of Opiate Drug Abuse
column2: nomorepills, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was a long time pill user that went through the Rapid Drug Detox at one of a few facilities in the U.S.  After detox the doctor put me on this med.   Appears to be working good as I have no cravings for pills (opiates).  And the med. has not caused any issues,  I think it's going to work and I was clearly ready to stop the madness too.

column1: Prevention of Opiate Drug Abuse
column9: I stopped abusing narcotic painkillers cold turkey with Naltrexone. I went from 14-15 pills a day to ZERO! The only side effect for me: I get a little anxious right after taking it and that lasts for about 30 minutes. I don't know if you can truly understand how amazing it is to go from 14-15 pills a day to ZERO without withdrawal, unless you experience the hurt of addiction. The only precaution that my doctor didn't tell me about is that if you take it within 7-10 days of taking narcotics it will INSTANTLY cause amplified withdrawal for about the first few hours or so. Stop taking whatever you're taking and as you get closer to needing a fix, take Naltrexone instead and you should be fine. This medication makes me indifferent to narcotics. I have been offered pills since I started treatment and they don't even appeal to me. I literally cannot even remember or feel the allure, attraction or reason behind my drug abuse. I don't even think about it anymore. It's always a good idea to seek treatment, counseling or 12 -Step Recovery. Don't just stop your substance abuse but seek to recognize underlying issues that drive you to chemicals in the first place.

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: istamaza, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: i was a heavy drinker and had gotten into trouble. i was prescribed this and have remained for sober for almost 5 years. i truly believe this drug works for those of us who drank heavily periodically, quit for a month or two, drank again, quit again. this drug is great for those of us who tend to "binge drink" and drink to get drunk. very wonderful feeling being sober with little to no side effects...awesome!!

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: lbellm, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Having had a severe drinking problem for over 30 years, my psychiatrist gave me an Rx for Naltrexone.  I started on 12/27/10 with 25mg for 3 days and then went to 50mg.  I have had absolutely no side effects.  I haven't wanted to drink since that day.  I'm able to go to bars with other people drinking and it doesn't bother me.  It's like a miracle to me.....why didn't I get this sooner?  I know I'm very lucky, as I've heard from many people that it has not worked for them.  From research I've found it appears to help women more than men, although they don't know exactly why.  There is also a "gene" factor involved in why this drug works for some people and not others.  But I think everyone should at least try this medication.  You may be one of the ones it works for.  I wish it worked for everyone like it does for me.  I definately know the pain of alcoholism.  I have a whole new life ahead of me.

The first day I was real tired, the next few days I just felt strange, by the fifth day my body adjusted and this is nothing short of a miracle drug for me.  It's not a drug for those still drinking or drinking occassionally!  Stop and use this, along with counseling, etc. this could be very effective for those that can tolerate it.

column1: Other
column2: trich, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: My daughter has been diagnosed with trichotilomania (hair pulling) and there have been a few staudies that naltrexone may be helpful b/c it blocks the pleasure center. It is however generally used for drug and alcohol intervention. She took the lowest dose (25mg) and found some improvement at first but then no greater improvement. Our psychiatrist upped the meds to 50 and then finally 75 over a period of a couple of months to no more success. We have stopped taking it and are trying N-Aceyl-Cysteine (NAC) supplement instead.

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am a 34yr old working mother, and had a problem with alcohol for the past 2 years. I did not grow up with alcohol and didn't drink until I was 30yrs old. I drank due to stress in my life. After trying to quit dozens of times wrecking my car and almost loosing my husband, I went to a non-traditional rehab program that used Naltrexone. I received the Vivitrol inj. and am also using campral and Zofran. The results are amazing. My craving for alcohol went down to almost nothing, it helped with my anxiety and just put me on an even playing ground to be able to resist temptation. I did have some nausea and a headache as side effect, but I consider that minor for getting my life back. I've been sober 52 days!!!!

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Today is my first day and I just took a 1/2 a pill.  I haven't NOT drank AT LEAST a bottle of wine or champagne (and usually more) for years.  I had some dizziness and a little "buzz" with this drug today.  That started an hour after I took my 1st 1/2 pill, and lasted for about 3.5 hours.  BUT I had to small glasses of wine with dinner (probably 6 ounces total) and corked the bottle!  I didn't know you didn't HAVE TO FINISH IT!  The wine was good, but more for accompanying dinner (brie, chocolate) instead of getting hammered.  So far, so good.  I'll post later too.

column1: Other
column2: Carol, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have only been on it about a week (1-6-10 = first doese). The first day I experienced nausea badly enough I felt I was going to throw up.  I went off it a day, then back on.  I had persistent low-grade nausea but not bad enough I ceased to take it.  I felt the end justified the means - I needed it badly enough to treat my cancer that I could put up with some nausea.  In only about a week the excurciating pain associated with the cancer in my pelvis is almost gone.  The pain was to the point I was almost immobile. It had been growing progressively intense since about March.  It is now more like an irritation.  I also had a sore about the size of a lima bean (a little thicker) on my hand. The area was red, scabbed. Touching it caused pain throughout my body. It bled easily.  That sore had been growing on my hand for about a month. Now, the sore is almost gone. There is one minor red spot, and one minor scab. The area is no longer sore to the touch. It does not bleed. I believe the same thing is going on inside my body to the cancer in my pelvis.

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: TREVONBACH, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: as a case-a-night drinker, i took half of a naltrexone as prescribed one night during a blackout. the next morning i felt odd, dizzy and as if on laughing gas, but took the last half of the pill. i slept most of the day and woke up only to take another pill that evening. the following day i had no urge or even need to drink. it took a few months to mentally, initially take the med knowing it was going to change my life. after a month and a few days i have yet to need or want a drop of alcohol. i highly recommend this med, but at the same time i must tell you it took some getting used to. it made me feel catatonic in the first few days, like walking in a daze. but now that i am used to it i basically drink a lot of coffee to get thru the day and then, when i am finally feeling back to level - headed, i take another pill, just before bed. it has also helped in my insomnia. i have changed my sedentary lifestyle to swimming 3x a week, and already in a week i have lost 6 pounds, but thats literally more of a workout than walking to the fridge every 10 minutes, and the "12-oz curls"... overall i am extremely pleased. my only issue with this drug is twofold:what happens when you stop taking them? is there a huge withdrawal from the naltrexone that basically i avoided when taking them over that one weekend? or is all well and you just go on...and secondly, needing oral surgery soon, will this affect my ability to block pain from whatever scripts they give me? what other prescription meds beyond opiods are ok to use with this drug that will not give me a dependence towards it other than ibuprofen/acetaminophen/aspirin...?thanks webmd for allowing this forum to be printed and read. i found alot of good helpful reviews on this website today and decided to contribute. (BTW... Chantix is great to quit smoking, Naltrexone is just as effective for drinking, minus the "high - definition" dreams.)

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 41 year old mother of four-two of my children are autistic. I was seeking help to get through the day with pain killers and alcohol. My doctor convinced me to take Naltrexone for potential weight loss. Weight loss happens in less than 10% of users. I didn't lose weight. I did not crave alcohol for a while but after about three months the cravings returned, only now with Naltrexone, much greater amounts of alcohol must be consumed for the effect of relaxation, etc.I think I will stop taking it.

column1: Prevention of Opiate Drug Abuse
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been using this for over 6 years.  I have found it to be very effective.  It has reduced cravings for opiates.  However, this drug is not a miracle drug.  It needs to be used along with support and other methods.  I also think that it takes some time for it to work.  I was actually doing well, and after taking it for five years, i began to forget to take it and stopped getting it refilled.  This was not intentional; it just wasn't a concern.  About 3 weeks after, I had very strong cravings and could actually taste drugs in my throat as if I had done them.  Follow your doctors instructions, and continue to take it even if you are doing well until your doctor tells you otherwise.  Also, question your doctor if you are told to take this while still using.  As said in the information on this drug, this can cause intense withdraw symptoms.  For those of you who just started taking it, give it a chance.  When I began with it, I was given it in an implant form, put into my body below my stomach.  This gave me no choice but to take it, and I am grateful.  I was also told by my doctor that intentially not taking it in order to get the full effect of opiates is dangerous because it has changed your bod, and puts people at an increased risk for overdose.  Of all those I know that use opiates, I am the only one taking naltrexone, and also the only one that is still clean.

column1: Habit of Drinking Too Much Alcohol
column2: cMB, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was put on this when I told my dr I was wanting to stop drinking, had hit rock bottom. This works for me very well, have one more refill. It made drinking less and less satisfying over time and now I've gone 2 weeks without one, my liver is nearly 100% back to normal, I do plan on starting therapy though as a 2nd part of treatment. Hope this helps and good luck.

column1: Other
column2: Anna, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been taking this medication for MS for about three weeks; definately not enough time to see any benefit.  My first month's dosage is 3mg every night at bedtime, then I start taking 4.5mg.  My neurologist hopes to reduce my need for i.v. solumedrol as I've been receiving that for 11 years (and prednisone/deltasone 7 years before that) -- definately bad for my bones!  I plan on giving this drug a fair trial, and I hope it works, but yesterday I took it long before bedtime, and I ended up dizzy and staggering around the house with stomach cramps until I eventually threw up.  So in the future I will ALWAYS take this medication before I fall asleep!  I've also noticed easier bruising, and I've been having some vivid dreams, and twice my husband had trouble waking me where I am usually an incredibly light sleeper.

column1: Other
column2: Kristie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I use low dose naltrexone for MS.. It halts the progress & symptom lessening or disappearance is a bonus.  I have gotten by balance back almost 100% & my vision is improving.  I have been on it for 3 wks.  Starting at 1.5mg for 1 wk then upped to 3mg.
